We arrived to Hackberry Cottage later in the evening after the sun had set. Pulling up to it, Ginger had the lights on and we could see it looked lovely! Communication with her throughout our stay was fantastic.
Inside was clean and very inviting. There were treats and a sign greeting us when we walked in as well as Christmas decorations and music playing lowly from the living room TV. She mentions antiques in her listen, and they are gorgeous. Additional, should you look closely, some artwork on the walls is by the host herself!
There was everything you could possibly need and more. My children thought the “secret room” (a small nook/nursery off the master) and balcony were the best thing!
We stayed in town for my fall graduation from Truman, but all agreed we should make a plan to come back in the summer to be able to enjoy the outdoor spaces. (It was colder and rainy.)
I’ll end with this wasn’t just the loveliest Airbnb we’ve stayed at but the loveliest place in general!

We stayed at Gina's place for graduation weekend in May at Truman. The cabin is in a small clearing with surrounding woods--very private and peaceful. It's about a 15 minute drive from the Truman State campus. It worked well for our family. There's a fire pit/fire ring on the property and Jay was kind enough to provide some firewood for us to have a bonfire one night. Both Gina and her husband Jay were very responsive before and during our stay. Guests should be aware that Hungry Hollow Rd leading to the cabin off Hwy 63 is a country gravel road, fairly narrow and some hills, so drivers will need to go slow (you might want 4 WD in winter driving conditions). A window air conditioning unit cools the house in warmer months. Best to keep doors to the bedrooms open at night if you want them to be cool (especially the bedroom furthest from the unit). We enjoyed our stay and we wouldn't hesitate to book again!
-Patty

Small, but lovely!
My friend and I stayed 2 nights at this cabin. It was cozy, the hosts communicated well, and we had just about everything we needed.
It's small, as listed, so I found it most ideal for two people, but the host offers an inflatable mattress if desired/needed for up to 4 guests. It's in a pretty location, though the distance from nearby towns is something to consider (I didn't mind the drive, others might).
I found the furnishings charming, and it's packed with books to read, card and board games to play, and media players for dvds, cds, and even records. There's internet, but you could certainly find entertainment the whole stay without it.
The listing fails to mention the incinerator toilet though, and there is no door on the bathroom, just a curtain. These things are manageable, but somewhat unpleasant surprises. I also found their cookware to be too small to properly cook for two people.
The pros outweigh the cons though, and I plan to visit again someday.

The Hilltop Farmhouse was absolutely awesome in terms of accommodations, scenery and location.

Our objectives in visiting Kirksville were for for peace and quiet, wildlife watching, and to visit the conservation areas and state parks nearby.

The farmhouse itself was beautiful, spacious, and we loved the wrap-around porch. It was secluded and very private.

The wildlife was abundant. Off the porch or nearby, we saw deer, turkeys, squirrels, opossums, raccoons, red-tailed hawks, Canada geese, bats, and more. We heard barred owls, great horned owls, and the crème de la crème: three sets of coyotes howling at each other.

The location was great – secluded and private, yet close to Kirksville and other scenic locations. We visited Thousand Hills State Park (literally across the road – although the main area was a short trip by vehicle), Union Ridge Conservation Area, Atlanta-Long Branch Conservation Area, as well as Truman State University and A.T. Still University. We also went to church on Sunday in town. All in all, a wonderful and relaxing weekend.

We plan to visit again.
